results.adx_keywords: your-feed-science;Medical Devices;Cameras;Digestive Tract;Bacteria;Consumer Protection;Defective Products;Food and Drug Administration;Olympus Corp;United States
results.title: These Devices Sickened Hundreds. The New Models Have Risks, Too.
results.abstract: Duodenoscopes — tubular cameras threaded into the intestine — with disposable parts were supposed to be safer. But the parts can fall off in the body, the F.D.A. warned.

media.caption: Duodenoscopes, which enter the upper part of the small intestine through the mouth to diagnose and treat diseases of the pancreas and the bile duct, are used in about 500,000 procedures a year in the U.S.

results.adx_keywords: Explosions (Accidental);Fires and Firefighters;Factories and Manufacturing;internal-storyline-no;Deaths (Fatalities);RM Palmer Co;West Reading (Pa)
results.byline: By David DeKok, Amanda Holpuch and Michael Levenson
results.title: Chocolate Factory Explosion Leaves at Least Three People Dead and Four Missing
results.abstract: One person was found alive overnight in the rubble after the explosion at the R.M. Palmer Company chocolate factory in West Reading, Pa., on Friday, officials said.

media.caption: A screen grab from a video shows the aftermath of an explosion at the R.M. Palmer Company plant in West Reading, Pa., on Friday.

results.adx_keywords: Defense and Military Forces;Russian Invasion of Ukraine (2022);Frauds and Swindling;Firearms;Reserves (Military);United States Marine Corps;United States Army;Defense Department;United States Navy;Georgia (Georgian Republic);Ukraine;United States
results.byline: By Justin Scheck and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
results.title: Stolen Valor: The U.S. Volunteers in Ukraine Who Lie, Waste and Bicker
results.abstract: People who would not be allowed anywhere near the battlefield in a U.S.-led war are active on the Ukrainian front, with ready access to American weapons.

media.caption: Axel Vilhelmsen trained Ukrainian soldiers last year as part of the Mozart Group, which two former Marines established to help Ukraine. It disbanded after one founder sued the other, alleging theft and harassment.
media.copyright: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces;Military Bases and Installations;Names, Geographical;Pickett, George E;Barfoot, Van;United States Army;Defense Department;Fort Pickett (Va);Fort Barfoot (Va);Confederate States of America
results.title: Army Base Renamed for Native American War Hero, Replacing Confederate
results.abstract: In the first of nine scheduled redesignations, Fort Pickett in Virginia became Fort Barfoot in honor of Col. Van Barfoot, a Medal of Honor recipient.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

media.caption: From left, Margaret Nicholls, Col. Van Barfoot’s daughter; Senator Tim Kaine; and Tom Barfoot, Colonel Barfoot’s son, unveiling a sign with the new name of the fort in Blackstone, Va.
media.copyright: Parker Michels-Boyce for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Presidential Election of 2024;Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right;Conspiracy Theories;Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021);Trump, Donald J;Clifford, Stephanie (1979- );Bragg, Alvin;Republican Party;Waco (Tex)
results.byline: By Michael C. Bender and J. David Goodman
results.title: As Trump Rallies in Waco, His Followers Shore Up His 2024 Bid
results.abstract: Despite a pattern of dangerous, erratic behavior, the former president remains a strong front-runner for his party’s nomination. His durability stems from his most loyal supporters.

media.caption: Early polls show that former President Donald J. Trump has a commanding advantage in the 2024 Republican primary field, though surveys also suggest that many G.O.P. voters would prefer another nominee.
media.copyright: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: your-feed-science;Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);Vaccination and Immunization;Elderly;Immune System;Food and Drug Administration
results.title: Should You Get Another Covid Booster?
results.abstract: Britain and Canada have authorized another round of booster shots for older and immunocompromised citizens. So far, U.S. officials haven’t followed suit.

media.caption: A woman receiving a fourth shot in September in Phoenix. While a Covid infection can be a matter of inconvenience for some, it can spell severe disease, hospitalization and death for older adults and immunocompromised people.
media.copyright: Ash Ponders for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Wildlife Die-Offs;Fish and Other Marine Life;Agriculture and Farming;Rivers;Floods;Murray-Darling Basin (Australia);New South Wales (Australia);Australia
results.byline: By Yan Zhuang and Michaela Skovranova
results.title: A River Choking on Fish Corpses, and a Community Full of Anger
results.abstract: It’s the latest clash over a river basin in New South Wales, Australia, in an arid land where social, economic and environmental interests collide over water issues.

media.caption: Millions of dead fish floating along parts of the lower Darling River in Menindee, Australia, on Wednesday.

results.adx_keywords: Securities and Commodities Violations;Virtual Currency;Fugitives;Extradition;Kwon, Do;Terraform Labs PTE Ltd;Montenegro
results.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany, John Yoon and Karoun Demirjian
results.title: A Crypto Fugitive’s Very Public Life While on the Run
results.abstract: Do Kwon, the founder of the failed crypto company Terraform Labs, is facing charges by the authorities in both South Korea and the United States.

media.caption: On Thursday, Do Kwon, the founder of Terraform Labs, was arrested in Podgorica, the capital of Montenegro, as he and a travel companion tried to board a private flight.

results.adx_keywords: Aurora Borealis;Earth;Solar Energy;Space and Astronomy;Weather;National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration;United States;North Carolina
results.title: The Northern Lights Were Seen Farther South in the United States
results.abstract: A powerful geomagnetic storm helped to make the colorful aurora visible in places like North Carolina and Arizona on Thursday night.

media.caption: A powerful geomagnetic storm caused the northern lights to stretch southward in the United States on Thursday night.

results.adx_keywords: Cemeteries;Parks and Other Recreation Areas;Parks and Recreation Department (NYC);Human Resources Administration (NYC);Hart Island (Bronx, NY);New York City
results.title: A Million Bodies Are Buried Here. Now It’s Becoming a Park.
results.abstract: Hart Island, a potter’s field where New York City has buried its unclaimed dead for more than a century, will finally accept visitors this year.

media.caption: The city still conducts about 1,100 burials every year on Hart Island, adding to the million bodies already buried there. The graves will remain undisturbed as Hart Island is opened to the public.

results.adx_keywords: Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides;Fashion and Apparel;Fentanyl;Lady Gaga;Gallagher, Kathryn Marie (1986-2022);Office of the Chief Medical Examiner of the City of New York;Manhattan (NYC)
results.title: Overdose Death of Designer Who Dressed Lady Gaga Is Ruled a Homicide
results.abstract: Kathryn Marie Gallagher, 35, whose body was found in her apartment in July, died from a lethal mix of fentanyl and alcohol, the New York City medical examiner said.
org_facet: Office of the Chief Medical Examiner of the City of New York

media.caption: Kathryn Gallagher, inspired by girlhood days in the woods, cultivated a Gothic aesthetic.
media.copyright: Deidre Schoo for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: United States Politics and Government;Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021);Prison Guards and Corrections Officers;Prisons and Prisoners;Greene, Marjorie Taylor (1974- );District of Columbia Jail;Washington (DC)
results.title: Lawmakers Tour D.C. Jail Where Jan. 6 Defendants Are Held
results.abstract: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene said the detainees had reported mistreatment, but a Democratic lawmaker said their conditions were better than others.

media.caption: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene previously visited the jail in November 2021 and wrote a report about the conditions there. This time, she said they had improved.

results.adx_keywords: Exercise;Health Clubs
results.title: Think Getting Into College Is Hard? Try Applying for These Gyms.
results.abstract: A new crop of luxury gyms requires referrals, interviews and even, in some cases, medical evaluations. And that’s before paying a monthly fee of up to $2,750.

media.caption: Ghost, a gym in Williamsburg, is part of a new crop of luxury fitness centers requiring an extensive application process. “If you’re making widgets in Akron, Ohio, they may not want you,” said the founder of another gym.

results.adx_keywords: Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);Long Covid;Chronic Condition (Health);Research;Diabetes;Vaccination and Immunization;Obesity;your-feed-healthcare;JAMA Internal Medicine (Journal)
results.title: Who Is Most at Risk for Long Covid?
results.abstract: A new analysis summarizes the emerging picture of factors that make long-term post-Covid symptoms more likely.

media.caption: A patient living with long Covid since her infection in March 2020 in Massachusetts. The analysis involved a total of 860,783 patients and found patients were more likely to be female.

results.title: The Income Gap Is Becoming a Physical-Activity Divide
results.abstract: Nationwide, poor children and adolescents are participating far less in sports and fitness activities than their more affluent peers.

media.caption: Naomi Peralta, at left, prepares for a practice run at Highland High School in Albuquerque, N.M., in February.
media.copyright: Adria Malcolm for The New York Times

results.byline: By Holcomb B. Noble and Katie Hafner
results.title: Gordon E. Moore, Intel Co-Founder Behind Moore’s Law, Dies at 94
results.abstract: His prediction in the 1960s about rapid advances in computer chip technology charted a course for the age of high tech.

media.caption: Gordon E. Moore in 1990 at the Silicon Valley headquarters of Intel, which he founded in 1968 with Robert Noyce.

results.adx_keywords: your-feed-science;your-feed-health;Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);Autism;Children and Childhood;Disabilities;Centers for Disease Control and Prevention;United States
results.title: Autism Prevalence Rises Again, Study Finds
results.abstract: The pandemic may have disrupted the detection of autism spectrum disorder in young children, researchers also reported.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

media.caption: The rise in autism’s prevalence could stem from several factors, including increased awareness and screening.

results.adx_keywords: Writing and Writers;Shoes and Boots;Santiago de Compostela (Spain)
results.title: Whatever the Problem, It’s Probably Solved by Walking
results.abstract: A walk begins to carve out space between my thoughts that allows clarity to rise up through my shoes.

results.byline: By Rick Rojas, Sarah Kramer Ozbun, Emily Cochrane and Richard Fausset
results.title: At Least 26 Killed as Powerful Tornado Tears Through Mississippi
results.abstract: Dozens more were injured after a deadly tornado ripped through a rural area. The death toll is expected to rise.

media.caption: Silver City, Miss., in the aftermath of a tornado that sliced through the area on Friday night.

results.title: What’s Behind the ‘Middle-Aged Groan’?
results.abstract: Experts weigh in on the sounds we make when we bend over, stand up and sit down.
